diagrams.description: 3D printing's origins trace to 1984 when Chuck Hull invented stereolithography (SLA) and coined the term 3D printing. 1986 saw Hull founding 3D Systems and filing the SLA patent. 1988 introduced Selective Laser Sintering (SLS) by Carl Deckard at University of Texas. 1989 brought Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) development by Scott Crump (Stratasys founded). The 1990s witnessed industrial adoption for rapid prototyping, multiple 3D printing companies emerging, and early bioprinting research. 2005 marked the RepRap project launch by Adrian Bowyer, initiating the open-source 3D printing movement. 2009 saw FDM patents expiring, enabling affordable consumer 3D printers. The 2010s brought explosive growth with desktop 3D printers (MakerBot, Ultimaker), metal 3D printing advancements, bioprinting progress (organ printing research), and aerospace adoption (GE printing fuel nozzles). 2013 introduced carbon fiber 3D printing. The 2015-2020 period witnessed multi-material printing, continuous printing technologies (CLIP), and construction-scale 3D printing. The 2020s continue with mass customization, metal printing for production parts, 4D printing (shape-changing materials), AI-optimized designs, sustainable materials, and space manufacturing applications becoming reality.
diagrams.mermaid_code:
timeline
    title: The History of 3D Printing
    section: The 1980s - The Birth of Additive Manufacturing
        1981: Hideo Kodama's rapid prototyping system
        1986: Chuck Hull patents Stereolithography (SLA)
        1987: Carl Deckard patents Selective Laser Sintering (SLS)
        1989: S. Scott Crump patents Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM)
    section: The 1990s - Commercialization and Growth
        1990s: The first commercial 3D printers are sold
        1999: The first 3D-printed organ (a bladder) is implanted
    section: The 2000s - The Open Source Revolution
        2005: The RepRap Project, a self-replicating 3D printer, is founded
        2009: MakerBot is founded
    section: The 2010s - The Age of the Consumer
        2010s: Expiration of key patents leads to a boom in consumer 3D printing
        2014: 3D printing is used to create a prosthetic jaw
    section: The 2020s - The Industrial Revolution
        2020s: 3D printing is increasingly used for mass production
        2020s: Advancements in metal 3D printing and bioprinting
